ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned what nanomaterials are, and how they are made, used, and characterized. It was a thorough summary of zero-, one-, and two-dimensional materials followed by a unit on different kinds of microscopy. Some pset problems as well as the presentation and term paper required reading scientific literature on nanomaterials, so I believe I got better at reading scientific papers through this class.
I learned a lot of new and interesting info about nano materials and technology
I learned about the synthesis and properties of nanomaterials such as quantum dots, nanowires, and thin-film materials. We learned about microscopy of nanomaterials and their applications.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
It's pretty much all strengths. Students have opportunities to investigate unexplored content in both the presentation and term paper. I like how the grading is spread evenly across homework, exam, presentation, and paper so as not to favor one type of learner in particular.

I guess occasionally I didn't quite know what was going on in lecture. This is partly because the course is co-listed as a grad school course so Prof. Cha had to keep it interesting for more knowledgeable people. But as long as I knew what questions to ask, she was ready with a clarification.

The main weakness is that Judy Cha is leaving for Cornell at the end of this school year and future students won't get a chance to take this course with her.

If you're an undergraduate student, this course may be a bit more challenging. Many grad students had the advantage of performing research in the field, and so had a much better understanding of the topics. A lot of it was difficult to grasp without practical application
One strength was the ability for students to take classes remotely or in person. This ensured that one can get the material of the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if the next professor is as organized as Prof. Cha.
Yes, if you're into doing a lot of independent readings to understand the questions asked in the psets; sometimes the questions are hard to understand without further research
I would recommend the course because there is a lot of material covered in the course in a digestible way.
